Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Integrating Electrical Flux Metrology with Third Party Machine tools for Precision On-board Measurements
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will quantify the reliability of Electrical Flux Metrology (EFM) technology, compare its precision against existing state-of-the-art metrology processes, and verify the portability onto a third party machine tool. One of the greatest obstacles in machining micro-parts is inspection and verification. Prospective customers, partners and investors currently considering EFM technology do not have a measure for comparison that demonstrates how this new product will fit their process demands and portfolios. This project will (1) define a figure of merit for metrology standards with respect to precision and uncertainty. It will (2) directly compare the capabilities of EFM technology to the current state-of-the-art technologies of optical scanning and coordinate measurement machines. Finally, It will (3) integrate the EFM technology onto a third-party machine tool to verify the portability of the technology and determine how it alters the base figure of measurement. This is a non-contact and non-destructive in-situ metrology process, allowing parts machined on a platform to be measured and re-machined on the same platform. Comparing and integrating the EFM technology will verify the precision of this new technology. The result of this project will provide vital commercialization components and prove marketability.


The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is focused toward miniaturized products with micro-sized features and applications that are rapidly expanding in the medical, automotive, and aerospace industries. As an example, the minimally invasive medical products market, supported by micro-metrology, was a $19 Billion industry in 2011. One of the most challenging aspects to micro-manufacturing is inspection of machined features. New manufacturing and hybrid processes to improve throughput and reduce operator time and material waste are required and addressed with the EFM technology, an elegant on-board metrology solution for micro-parts. As the parts and features of parts get smaller, better metrology is required. The EFM technology allows features to be measured that were previously only possible through destructive testing. This technology will advance micro-manufacturing and allow for higher precision parts to be manufactured more effectively. The micro manufacturing market is desperately asking for improved metrology of small features. EFM technology will fill this void. The commercial potential for this product is significant and will create new manufacturing jobs. Companies, small and large, will integrate this technology directly into the manufacturing process flow. This technology will enhance the manufacturing of improved and advanced micro-parts and micro-features in products.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Integrating Electrical Flux Metrology with Third Party Machine Tools for Precision On-board Measurements

 

This small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I grant quantified, verified and compared the precision of the Electrical Flux Metrology (EFM) process with current state-of-the-art metrology technologies. This is a non-contact and non-destructive metrology process. One of the greatest obstacles in machining micro-parts is inspection. Conventionally, parts are machined on one platform and measured by another separate and dedicated platform. When a critical dimension is out of tolerance, the part is replaced within the machining platform for additional work. However, as features and tolerances reduce to microns it is impossible for these parts to be re-positioned, once removed. These parts are scrapped, the process corrected and new parts are manufactured in their place, costing time, material waste, and energy. The development of an elegant and effective in situ metrology process reduces this waste. The EFM process will become as common within a process flow as a tool change. With this technology, anything machined on a CNC platform is measurable and re-machinable on the same platform without losing positional accuracies. Work completed during this grant defined a quantifiable measure of comparison of the EFM technology with existing metrology technologies for marketing and commercialization purposes.

            Analysis from this grant quantified the reliability of Electrical Flux Metrology (EFM) and directly compared its precision with existing state-of-the-art metrology processes. It also verified the portability of the process, and its capabilities, onto third party CNC machine tools. Customers, partners and investors considering the EFM technology now have a quantified base of comparison when considering how it will fulfill their process demands. A secondary result of this research provided vital commercialization components and demonstrated the competitiveness of this product.

            The defined figure of merit (FOM) for EFM metrology is the standard deviation of the measurements with a defined error as outside 99.7% compliance (3σ point). Thirty individual coordinates were measured, each along the three orthogonal axes. Each coordinate/axes couplet was measured 1,000 times for each of four Micro-manufacturing specific materials (total = 360,000 samples). The FOM was extracted from this data for Stainless Steel (48nm), Tungsten Carbide (60nm), Titanium (56nm) and Platinum (90nm). This, coupled with errors of a few hundred nanometers per materials, makes this a very precise, repeatable and reliable process.

            EFM metrology results of a defined unique work-piece were directly compared with the results from optical scanning and coordinate measurement machines of the same work-piece. These comparisons demonstrated how the EFM technology scanned at similar rates and with similar precisions to the CMM technology. Whereas the CMM scan left obvious scratches and witness marks along the serpentine path of its scan, the EFM technology left the part in its original state, even after doing a scan of the entire part. However, when compared with optical scans, the EFM process was slower and collected less complex data sets, such as color. In both comparisons though, the EFM process is able to measure smaller holes and slots, and features with higher aspect ratios and complexity than the other technologies. All third-party measurements required a clean work-piece and conducted in QA/QC environments. The EFM scan of the part ran in an active mach...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Integrating Electrical Flux Metrology with Third Party Machine Tools for Precision On-board Measurements This small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I grant quantified, verified and compared the precision of the Electrical Flux Metrology (EFM) process with current state-of-the-art metrology technologies. This is a non-contact and non-destructive metrology process. One of the greatest obstacles in machining micro-parts is inspection. Conventionally, parts are machined on one platform and measured by another separate and dedicated platform. When a critical dimension is out of tolerance, the part is replaced within the machining platform for additional work. However, as features and tolerances reduce to microns it is impossible for these parts to be re-positioned, once removed. These parts are scrapped, the process corrected and new parts are manufactured in their place, costing time, material waste, and energy. The development of an elegant and effective in situ metrology process reduces this waste. The EFM process will become as common within a process flow as a tool change. With this technology, anything machined on a CNC platform is measurable and re-machinable on the same platform without losing positional accuracies. Work completed during this grant defined a quantifiable measure of comparison of the EFM technology with existing metrology technologies for marketing and commercialization purposes. Analysis from this grant quantified the reliability of Electrical Flux Metrology (EFM) and directly compared its precision with existing state-of-the-art metrology processes. It also verified the portability of the process, and its capabilities, onto third party CNC machine tools. Customers, partners and investors considering the EFM technology now have a quantified base of comparison when considering how it will fulfill their process demands. A secondary result of this research provided vital commercialization components and demonstrated the competitiveness of this product. The defined figure of merit (FOM) for EFM metrology is the standard deviation of the measurements with a defined error as outside 99.7% compliance (3σ point). Thirty individual coordinates were measured, each along the three orthogonal axes. Each coordinate/axes couplet was measured 1,000 times for each of four Micro-manufacturing specific materials (total = 360,000 samples). The FOM was extracted from this data for Stainless Steel (48nm), Tungsten Carbide (60nm), Titanium (56nm) and Platinum (90nm). This, coupled with errors of a few hundred nanometers per materials, makes this a very precise, repeatable and reliable process. EFM metrology results of a defined unique work-piece were directly compared with the results from optical scanning and coordinate measurement machines of the same work-piece. These comparisons demonstrated how the EFM technology scanned at similar rates and with similar precisions to the CMM technology. Whereas the CMM scan left obvious scratches and witness marks along the serpentine path of its scan, the EFM technology left the part in its original state, even after doing a scan of the entire part. However, when compared with optical scans, the EFM process was slower and collected less complex data sets, such as color. In both comparisons though, the EFM process is able to measure smaller holes and slots, and features with higher aspect ratios and complexity than the other technologies. All third-party measurements required a clean work-piece and conducted in QA/QC environments. The EFM scan of the part ran in an active machine shop within a di-electric bath and no special cleaning processes. The EFM technology was integrated onto a third-party CNC machine tool at a remote machine shop and its portability is verified. The FOM of this integrated system was determined to be 400nm – this is an expected reduction in precision, as the relays in the CNC system and its co...
